s.text: Glassman and Hassett write in to say I have misrepresented their argument.

Imagine how Slate and others would slice me up if you found out I was running a magazine about journalism--one that some call a "watchdog"--and was getting paid writing assignments from one of the organizations I was supposed to be watching and, of course, not disclosing it on the pages of the magazine whenever the magazine writes about that organization.

For those who can't wait until the fall release date of our book Dow 36,000 and want to start thinking through these issues, check out the Spring 1995 issue of the journal Contemporary Accounting Research , which provides a number of valuable review articles of the some of the relevant academic work.

My article does not say or imply that "real earnings growth only reflects retentions and that dividend growth must be zero" or that "all valuation techniques are out the window for firms that don't pay dividends."

Gottlieb's piece, in an easy-to-follow way, demonstrates Crook's argument that, if you value a firm by discounting its earnings, and all earnings are not paid out in dividends, then you are double-counting.

Say what?
and a portfolio manager who recommends stocks in a column of his own."
Cramer continues, "[T]here is no difference between a portfolio manager who recommends stocks in an interview to a reporter ...
One can want a particular practice to be rare just because it is painful, even if it is morally required (and not just permissible).

If it's true, then give up your $250,000 salary and your stock options in TheStreet.com, stop writing about your personal life in your musings, and remove the iconic projection of yourself from your Web site.

I have great respect and admiration for Marshall Loeb (that's not a throwaway line; I really do), but his explanation that he was getting paid by Time , not the advertisers, is kind of funny (see "Culturebox: ").

We treat that question at length in our book, relating the observation to theories at the frontier of the branch of economics known as "Industrial Organization," but here is a hint: The simplest textbook model of the perfectly competitive firm doesn't do a great job of describing the companies that have driven the market higher and higher.
What would a fair price for Microsoft be if the risk premium were zero?
What would a fair price for Microsoft be if the risk premium were zero?

For those who can't wait until the fall release date of our book Dow 36,000 and want to start thinking through these issues, check out the Spring 1995 issue of the journal Contemporary Accounting Research , which provides a number of valuable review articles of the some of the relevant academic work.

The general tone of Cramer's piece is dismissive of financial journalists (or at least those who would criticize him) as know-nothings or, worse, conspirers with the dark forces of the finance industry.
Might they add on assignments if a piece celebrates them?
